p.s: The given drama extract from Macbeth by Shakespeare, Act 1, Scene 7, published in the early 17th century, shows an argument between the protagonist Macbeth and his wife Lady Macbeth.
As Macbeth told his wife about the prophecy of him becoming king, she starts to plan to murder the present king Duncan.
In their argument, Macbeth tries to stop her from her thoughts of murdering him beacuse he has earned himself a high reputation.
She tells him that he is just not brave enough and that he has to do something, like murdering the kingKing, in order to keep his reputation.
At this point, he still does not want to go this far yet, but she convinces him anyways.
She insults him and says that he would not be a man if he did not do it.
He still is not sure and kind of afraid of failing, so she presents her exact plan of making the servants drunk to unguard Duncan.
Macbeth is competely convinced in the end and is impressed by her courage.
